para.paratext: Georgia defines relevant evidence in O.C.G.A. § 24-4-401 as “any evidence having any tendency to make the existence of a fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.” O.C.G.A. § 24-4-401 tracks the language of Federal Rule of Evidence 401 as it existed when the Evidence Code was drafted, and thus, our courts will look to the decisions of the federal appellate courts, especially the 11th circuit, instead of cases discussing cases under the old Evidence Code.[1] The test for relevance under Rule 401 is generally a liberal one.[2] This concept is viewed even more liberally in the context of striking allegations in a pleading.[3] Decisions regarding relevance are committed to the sound discretion of the trial court.[4]

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-4-402, all relevant evidence is admissible, except as limited by constitutional requirements or as otherwise provided by law or by other rules. No matter how slight the probative value, our law favors admission of relevant evidence.[5] The evidence need only tend to prove or disprove the material issue without consideration of its weight.[6] A trial court's ruling that evidence is relevant will not be reversed absent abuse of discretion.[7] Thus, the statutory scheme laid out by Rules 401, 402, and 403 is applicable to all evidence that a party seeks to present.[8] Under our new Evidence Code, the general admissibility of evidence is governed by O.C.G.A. § 24-4-401, which defines relevant evidence as evidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence. This determination is made by the trial judge pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-4-402, which provides that all relevant evidence shall be admissible, except as limited by constitutional requirements or as otherwise provided by law or by other rules, and O.C.G.A. § 24-4-403, which provides that relevant evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence. However, Rule 403 is an extraordinary remedy which the courts should invoke sparingly, and the balance should be struck in favor of admissibility.
For example, hearsay may be relevant, but excluded under the rule against hearsay.

Evidence not relevant to prove or disprove a material issue will be excluded. In Xpress Cargo Systems, Inc. v. McMath,[9] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the trial court properly excluded evidence that the plaintiff was an unlicensed driver when she drove into defendant's parked vehicle. The plaintiff's lack of a driver's license was inadmissible because there was no connection between this fact and the collision. The defendant argued that there was a causal connection because the plaintiff's impaired vision caused the collision and the plaintiff did not have a driver's license because of her impaired vision. The court rejected these arguments because the issue was whether the plaintiff's poor vision caused the accident, not whether she had a driver's license.[10]

In Barrett v. Burnette,[11] the Court of Appeals held that the trial court abused its discretion when it excluded all evidence related to alcohol consumption by the owner of a parked vehicle in an action for negligence brought by a driver who struck the parked car. The court reasoned that such a broad exclusion prevented the plaintiff from questioning the defendant regarding his recollection of the evening, and other witnesses about his demeanor, so that the probative value of the evidence was not tenuous because it went to the ultimate issue in the case.

In Carter v. State,[12] the trial court admitted a recording and transcript of a conversation between a third party and the defendant. The Georgia Supreme Court concluded that the portions of the conversation from the third party gave relevance to the answers provided by the defendant under Rule 402.

In Jones v. State,[13] the Georgia Supreme Court disallowed a photo of two co-defendants standing at the beach for lack of relevance. The court reasoned that at most the photograph established that the pair knew each other, a fact that was not in dispute.

In Heard v. Payne,[14] the Court of Appeals permitted evidence of a telephone conversation between one of the parties in a declaratory judgment action and a detective where the party made the call to the detective and informed the detective her lottery ticket was stolen, that she always played the same number, and that she did not remember where she purchased the ticket. The court reasoned that the testimony was highly relevant to the issue in the case, since the ticket was a quick pick by the computer, and the other party knew where the ticket was purchased.

Olds v. State, 299 Ga. 65, 786 S.E.2d 633 (2016). But see Ramirez v. State, 303 Ga. 232, 811 S.E.2d 416 (2018), where the court determined that probative value of evidence was so small that it failed the low hurdle of Rule 401.
Chappuis v. Ortho Sport & Spine Physicians Savannah, LLC, 305 Ga. 401, 825 S.E.2d 206 (2019).
City of Atlanta v. Bennett, 322 Ga. App. 726, 728(1), 746 S.E.2d 198 (2013).
Central of Georgia Railroad Company v. Ross, 342 Ga. App. 27, 32(2), 802 S.E.2d 336 (2017).
Chrysler Group, LLC v. Walden, 303 Ga. 358, 812 S.E.2d 244 (2018).
Xpress Cargo Systems, Inc. v. McMath, 225 Ga. App. 32, 481 S.E.2d 885 (1997).
Xpress Cargo Systems, Inc. v. McMath, 225 Ga. App. 32, 481 S.E.2d 885 (1997).

See also Fielding v. Driggers, 126 Ga. App. 365, 366, 190 S.E.2d 601 (1972), where a judgment for the defendant was reversed because the trial court charged the jury that the plaintiff was guilty of negligence per se, since he had been driving without a license. In its reversal, the Fielding court stated, “[T]he absence of a proper driver's license is irrelevant and not admissible unless there is a proximate causal connection.”
Barrett v. Burnette, 348 Ga. App. 838, 824 S.E.2d 701 (2019).
